Slow, nowhere to go

McCartney could be referring to the bands early days when time was moving slow since everything was less chaotic and the band was just trying to make it. He could also be referring to how long it was taking their manger Klein to get the new contract in order.
Lorry

A lorry is a British term that can be used to describe a large flatbed truck that carries goods, such as shipping containers and dry cargo containers.  In 1957, Lennon’s band at the time, the Quarrymen, arrived at the St. Peter’s Church in Woolton, Liverpool to play at the garden fete, on the back of a lorry. At times they would often play on the back of it as well. This was also the day when McCartney and Lennon met each other.



Both John and Paul were a part of the Quarrymen, and this was how the band often times got around.
Any jobber got the sack
A “jobber” is a middleman who purchases large quantities of goods for resale.  It specifically refers to those who buy and resell fuel, but can be used for any middleman.
Nowhere to go

In Paul McCartney’s original handwritten lyrics, “nowhere to go” was originally written as “know where to go.” Operating as a homophone, this last cry can be seen as Paul calling to his younger self, reflecting on the unraveling of his band while warning the consequences of losing direction (in Paul’s case, alcoholism and deep depression).

And in the middle of negotiations
 You break down

Legal dealings with Apple and within the band were going nowhere. Lennon and Harrison favored the appointment of Rolling Stones manager Allen Klein as their new chief adviser after the death of Brian Epstein, whilst McCartney wanted his new brother-in-law. For a short time, both were appointed as co-managers, but in the end Klein won out.



Allen Klein, left, with John and Yoko.

One, two, three, four, five, six, seven
 All good children go to Heaven
 One, two, three, four, five, six, seven
 All good children go to Heaven

A children’s rhyme, possibly symbolising a new life and new beginnings for the band’s members.

Charles Manson, who famously interpreted Beatles lyrics as satanic messages, scrawled this lyric on the Manson family front door.

One sweet dream
 Pick up the bags, get in the limousine
 Soon we’ll be away from here
 Step on the gas and wipe that tear away

McCartney accepting here that the future of the band together is now behind them. He creates the image of driving away from everything, leaving it behind. He sheds a tear, however, showing that it isn’t an easy thing to do for him.

Lennon announced that he was finished with the band in September 1969, so McCartney knew Abbey Road would be the last album the band ever made.

Out of college, money spent
 See no future, pay no rent
 All the money’s gone, nowhere to go

This verse pays lighthearted homage to the fact that the band’s easy days are over and that they have very real and very pressing adult concerns. It’s no longer all screaming crowds and unanimous acclaim for The Beatles – there are legal and personal problems for them to deal with.
You only give me your funny paper

“Funny paper” referring to financial reports, contracts and the like. McCartney’s relationship with Apple Co was at breaking point at the time of recording, and the battle between him, his bandmates and Apple Executives would not end for another half decade.

But oh, that magic feeling, nowhere to go
 Oh, that magic feeling, nowhere to go

These lines transcend the song as a whole. It harks back to when times for all of them, particularly John, were more simple. When having time to yourself with nothing to do and no hassle seemed mundane at the time; but now after fame and fortune are sought and longed after.
